segments.text: how do I do this?

He says, you just call a Colonel, I believe that fellow's name was, yeah, Colonel Green in the Pentagon and gave me the phone number and just tell him what your name is, what your present duty is, where you're stationed, and that you want to join the American Volunteer Group under General Claire Chanel.
Well, under Chanel.

So, next morning I called, well, in the night I started talking to a couple of friends of mine who had gone over to California from Florida, same base, you know, two of my flying buddies, Jim Cross and George Burgard.
They were much younger in the Air Force than I did.
As a matter of fact, didn't practically have a flying school.
And they liked the idea.
Dave wanted to go, and I said, well, when I call, I'll mention his name.
He said, okay.
And I was told, boy, it happens like that when you call.
So I called this Colonel Green, talked to his secretary, gave him a name, serial number, and all that type of stuff.
And that evening, I gave him the name of this Jim, George, Burgoyne Jim Cross.
That evening, there was a wire received from headquarters.
An old colonel, he was a major then, Dias, D-I-A-Z, I'll never forget it.
He called me in, and he said, Bob, what in the hell is this wire I've got?
He says, I'm giving instruction to release you from active duty and reserve duty immediately, and here's your order sending you to your home for subsequent release to go on another mission.
He said, what the hell is this all about?
So I told him.
Boy, he was madder than hell.
He said, well, why don't you talk about it?
I said, well, I didn't have a chance.
It was one of those things that came up.
He was mad to lose you.
Oh, yeah.
One of his key men.
Same way as them.
They had orders, too.
Yeah, they got orders, too.
Matter of fact, the same wire had all three names.
But I was a flight leader, so that's what he called me.
But he eventually understood and didn't hold anything.
It took about, well, I was gone in about 48 hours.
So you were out in L.A. at this time.
And they paid my way home with dollars.
They did.
And I was given instructions, subsequent instructions on telephone from Colonel Green's office.
I guess Colonel Green was a contact point.
I had the project in the munitions building.
Sure.
And I was just told to go home and stay there until they contacted me.
They figured I'd be around.
And so I went home, and got a telephone call to report to San Francisco on September the 21st, 1941.
And that was about two weeks off.
And they sent me an airline ticket, and I packed up my stuff and went to San Francisco.
And I forget what hotel.
buddies to be and a lot of other guys.
As a matter of fact, there was about thirty-five of us on this contingent.
There had already been two contingents shipped over.
And we were to go over on the Bosch Fontaine, a Dutch motor ship, to Rangoon, Burma by various different means.
It was a freighter?
No, it was awell, it was athey call it a motorboat because it was
propelled steamship, really.
Well, it wasn't steam, it was oil propelled.
Diesel.
Diesel, yeah.
But they call it the USS Boche Fontaine.
It's the bottom of the ocean now, by the way.
Some of the Japanese subsequently.
It was quite a motor ship.
It was diesel powered.
And it was strictly passenger, some freight.
They carried freight.
Well, I say it's a combination.
And about 35 of us guys
Two contingents, as I said, had already gone over, and we were to go to Tongu, Burma, right in the central part of Burma, by way of Rangoon.
And it was going to take us, but it so turned out we sailed on the 25th of September of 1941, and we docked at Rangoon October the 12th.
Wow, that's a long time.
That long.
We went to Hawaii, and then from Hawaii we sailed due south for a long, long time.
And I said, well, I found out even aboard ship that we were boarding the Japanese shipping lane for obvious reasons.
This was a Dutch, you know.
Sure.
This goes back to, I think, I initially made the comment to you.
I think it was Christmas Island we sailed right by.
We saw it one day.
But boy, it seemed like we were on that boat forever from Honolulu to Surabaya, Java.
That was the first stop.
Well, we picked up a pilot.
off of Sydney, right here.
No, Townsville.
Picked up a poly right off Townsville, Australia, and we came on back down and sailed and came into Surabaya, Java.
And it was there, Surabaya is quite a Dutch port, and we could see fortifications being put in then.
against the Japanese.
My passport, I was a clerk.
Is that what it said on it?
I had to sever.
As a matter of fact, I even had to resign my reserve commission.
Oh, okay.
I wanted to know about that.
What happened as far as the U.S. military is concerned?
Because you were really getting out of the service.
As a matter of fact, I was told through this Colonel Green's office that when you come back,
But would you lose time?
No.
How did that work?
Would you lose time and grade?
I had to get out.
I had to resign from the service.
And he gave me an honorable discharge.
And I also had to resign my reserve commission, which was sort of an unusual thing.
I had to reserve all relations with the U.S. military.
And upon return,
I would be reinstated with my reserve commission, and it was debatable for longevity purpose of entity pay whether that one year would be held out or not.
But subsequently, I was found out that they did not give me credit for that one year of service on my, figured my longevity pay.
But my commission was dated back
The day I got out of the service was actually, it was dated back to September the 20th, sometime in September.
When I re-entered the service on October the 9th, I think, 1942, no, 43, when I got back home.
41, no wait, 42.
My reserve commission was dated back to make it continuous, but my active duty service was picked up the day I returned to the military, so it got me here.
And I went back, by the way, as second lieutenant.
One week later, I was promoted to captain.
Another week, I was promoted to major.
The following week, I was promoted to lieutenant colonel.
It was that understanding when I went back to the service.
Well, what do you mean that?
Well, I'm getting way ahead of myself.
This is when I got out of the Flying Tiger and came back home.
They tried to induct us over there, you know.
No.
To stay right on the job.
But the way they were doing it.
Well, we'll get to that.
Let's get to that.
But now let's go.
I just wanted to find out the legality of how the service would allow one of their own pilots to become a volunteer.
And then what would happen?
to have a military career.
Well, I dare say all of this was foreseen by the administration from the president on down.
Look, we know we're going to be in a war with the Japanese.

I've heard subsequently through political channels, diplomatic channels, subsequently in Russia, you know, amongst discussion with ambassadors and all, for instance Harriman, that Roosevelt supposedly made the comment that
One of the greatest solutions to one of the most difficult problems he ever had was when the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbor.
It made it simple for him.
He just declared war on them.
And he knew all along, eventually, he was going to be confirmed with the task of declaring war against Japan.
But this made it simple.
I don't know how true that is.
And I would be a bit surprised if he made that step.
Anyway.
So you got?
You were in the Far East.
They knew they'd eventually take us over as part of the Air Forces of, let's say, the Far East.
They knew they'd take us back.
And was the understanding that you could sign up for as many one-year tours of duties with Chenault and Spalding Tigers as you wanted?
Yeah, but the initial thing was for one year.
The contract was for one year, and then if we continued on, you could sign up for another year.
Your pay was a lot better.
Oh, I was getting about, if I remember correctly,
I was doing, as a second lieutenant in the Air Force, I think I was doing $100,000.
You were a first lieutenant now.
That's why I was doing $162 a month.
$162 as a first lieutenant?
Versus $600 a month.
Plus $500 for the airplane.
Plus all the expenses.
I didn't have to pay any money for any food or lodging.
And, of course, I was being trained in combat real estate.
What was it like, and where were you sent?
What base did you finally end up at?
The base, the initial training base, in the middle of, well, actually the first continued arrived in June of 1942 at Tongu, Burma, T-O-U-N-G-O-O, right in the middle of the center of Burma at an RAF.
They had the major control and influence in Burma.
As a matter of fact, they had- They were the British Empire.
Right, that's right.
And they had three or four air bases on them, one of which was Tangu.
Just a little tarmac strip, tarmac, British, is a mechanized strip about 2,000 feet long with a one hanger.
That was their training base.
Somehow or other,
through Lend-Lease, and I don't know the story of this, but the Chinese with the British agreed to let Chenault use this base in Burma to train the American Volunteer Group.
That's what it was called, American Volunteer Group.
We didn't even know what Flying Tiger was at that time.
And I think he was given a year to train the group and then move it up to China.
after we were trained.
He wanted freedom to train.
See, bases in China were being bombed at that time.
So he wanted freedom to train us.
But one of the stipulations was, and the freedom he was given, he chose the most experienced and capable pilots he could get.
He'd ask for the best.
He got the cream of crop of maintenance people, armorers, communications people, all the logistical support types, airmen,
Many of the guys were master sergeants of that type.
Their pay was ordinarily increased.
And nine-tenths of the guys were fighter pilots.
The Navy, the Army, the Army Air Corps, and the Marine Corps.
I think there were four Marine Corps.
All of them were.
Well, some of the guys in the Navy were bomber or attack pilots.
And I was accepted.
When Ault had it planned at that time, he had dreamed of really studying the entire Air Force and getting some bombers.
Ultimately, when he had the 14th Air Force inducted into the service of the general, the United States Air Force, then he did get some bombers over there.
And they visualized me being head of the bombing section when they got some B-17s.
And, boy, I dreamed of that.
But in the meantime, I was getting back fighters, P-40s.
I'd never flown a P-40 in my life.
OK. How about the training?
So we arrived at Tongu by train from Rangoon, and some of the boys had been there already, met us, took us out, put us up in the barracks, and we started our training.
How many were you?
The initial plan, ultimate plan, was for 100 pilots with 100 airplanes with a small staff for the group under Chenault himself, probably 15, 20 staff people.
and about 250 officers and officer types and airman types.
Total of about 275 in the entire group.
That's 275 Americans.
This is tantamount, this would be tantamount to a wing, a fighter wing in the United States Air Force, which on an ordinary base is around 4,100 people.
But, now you see, we would just be the tactical outfit that would fly up to China and be imposed
complete logistical organization of the Chinese Air Force, where they provided the messing, the fifth echelon maintenance and supply, and all of that stuff.
So was Chenault there when you arrived?
Chenault was already in China.
Was he training you down there?
Oh, yeah.
His main office was in China, Kunming, China.
We arrived, and well, since June, when the first contingent arrived, Tom Goo, he'd been spending most of his time at Tom Goo, you know, personally, with a few of his staff supervising the training.

And as he received us, you know, he gleaned over our records and so forth, and picked the better qualified people for the certain key staff, and then as he learned more about certain people, you know, maybe this guy was more of a communicator than he was a pilot, he may have pulled him, put him in the communication.
key staff members, like a material man.

One guy living out here in Abilene, Texas right now, Pepe Paxton, he turned out to be, well, he had an accounting degree and he was quite a financial type of guy, and he wasn't a pilot at all, to tell you the truth about it.
And he was a little bit older than the rest of us, so he made him his finance officer, that type of stuff.
So we had a going organization.
How good was the training?
The training was, the training
per se, I'd say was medium to good.
It wasn't the best in the world because I'd say 98% of the pilots that came over had never flown a P-40 before.
There'd only been one or two, I think, guys that had flown a P-40 before out of the airport.
Langley Field had just gotten some P-40s, I think.
And the rest of us were from other types of airplanes.
The few who would talk, then they taught others, and they taught others.
So the training really wasn't a big problem.
We were elite.
We were already trained people.
For instance, I was a bomber pilot.
You were getting used to the P-40.
That's right.
Being indoctrinated into, in other words, I was being re-equipped with a new airplane.
I had one in mind, too.
So you go on just training flights?
Training flights, get indoctrinated, and...
I had to rush through things.
Sure.
How long did you train?
Well, if I remember correctly, I think I had my first flight about the first of November.
I had about twelve hours in the P-40 on December 7th, when Warbrook moved.
But I had already been on several, oh, many combat missions where doing actual, you know, engaging in aerial combat
Matter of fact, I was, for the latter part of November, I was teaching some newcomers fighter tactics and P-40s.
I'd been on gunnery missions.
I'd never flown a gunnery mission, air-to-air gunnery mission.
My first mission was against Japanese bomber on December the 18th.
But I had done ground gunnery with a P-40.
I hadn't gotten to the point where I did air-to-air gunnery, as a matter of fact.
What did you think of the P-40?
I loved it.
As a matter of fact, first thing, I was back in the fighter.
And it was an inline engine, you know, and looked sleek, powerful.
You could turn a vertical dive and just go all out and never worry about anything coming loose.
It'd terminate around 450-something like that miles an hour and hold together.
How could you compare it, or would you compare it with the Japanese airplanes?
Well, that's what I'll get into, if it's okay.
Yeah, I'd like to do that.
I didn't meet a Japanese zero until Van Goon in February.
But I had utmost confidence in it.
And the key thing, though, was the knowledge that Chenault had of Japanese zeros and Japanese tactics as a result of being in China so long.
He personally taught the first guy that came over to the first contingent, and then, you know, he used them to teach us.
But even at times, he'd come in and give us talk.
personal talks.
And we had pictures of the Zeros, and then the old man here, his personal experience.
We were completely confident of what he was telling us.
And we were given, you know, he was the master of the flying in pairs, too.
He developed those tactics in the United States Air Force.
He's a master of that right now throughout the entire Air Force of the world.
always be at least two planes together.
And he knew the characteristics, flat characteristics of a P-40 compared to Zero.
Zero is an extremely maneuverable aircraft, very light.
The first one may have had no armor, protective armor in them at all.
And it had two 7.2
caliber guns in them, a little bit less than a .30 caliber.
We had two, we had four .30 calibers and a wing root of the P-40B, the first one we had, and two .50 calibers and a fuselage shooting through the propeller.
And we tried to cock the .50 calibers in a cockpit yourself, just manually.
You know, the butt of the gun sticking right out in front of your shoulder.
Whereas the
the 430s and the wings, you cocked and primed with hydraulic buttons.
Firepower, then.
Oh, yeah.
Oh, we had superior firepower.
We had superior speed, definitely in a dive.
What about flat out?
Flat out at altitude, we were just about equal.
As a matter of fact, at extreme altitudes, 0 to 21,000 feet, we were sort of at a disadvantage of zero.
We were a little bit faster.
But in a dive, the zero would have a terminal dive that was slower than us.
We were out diving.
But we wouldn't dare turn with it.
So we were given a tactic to use against the zero.
That's what we practiced and trained with.
You couldn't turn as fast as that?
Every turn, come in, hit and run tactics.

Hit and run tactics, keep up a high airspeed, and of course you could come in in the initial attack with a superior altitude, hit and break off, then go out, then come back, trying to reclimb into the altitude.
Try to maintain altitude, though.
and stay away from them from the standpoint of horizontal maneuvering.
And if they do happen to get on your tail, split us out and go into a high-speed dive to pull away from them.
And that's the way we fought them.
And I have nine and a quarter victories.
I'm almost a double ace.
Well, we're going to get to that.
We're going to get to those victories.
But I wanted to know now about when was your training completed?
Let's get back to the narrative.
My training wasn't completed.
And many of the pilots in my contingent, as a matter of fact, I think, if I remember correctly, there was one or two pilots that had not taken back.
Every pilot, we had about 15.

68 pilots at that time might continue came over at about the 68th pilot there was one more contingent the incident was in route and got just about the wake island on december the 7th and they turned it around saying back home that would have included the other 32 policies you would have had your hundred right but they sent them back home but so we started out with 68 pilots
And at that time, we probably had about 50 of the airplanes, 55 or maybe 60 of the airplanes, of the 100 P-40.
And I had, like I said, I think I had 12 hours.
And I have an old Chinese log book that I still keep.
So you had 12 hours of training.
12 hours of NAP-40 total on December the 7th, which included some gunnery missions.
See, I had a total of about...
When was your first mission?
You mean actual combat?
Yeah.
When were you first sent out to engage the enemy, if you did or not?
On December the 7th.
Of course, we went on December the 7th.
We got the news.
Pearl Harbor was hit and all of us were shocked.
Well, we immediately worked all night long, armed our guns full up.
We were ready to go to work because we thought we were going to be hit four days over.
And we immediately went on alert.
In other words, you were not hit at all, your air bases?
No, no.
Even though they were out?
Oh, okay.
Oh, they knew exactly what we were doing.
Oh, yeah.
Matter of fact, they knew we were polished when we came through Surabaya.
This stuff came out in the papers, the Japanese in the papers.
We know about the American Volunteer Group that continued coming through on the way to China, I mean to Burma.
We know where they're based and all, and said, you know, eventually we'll take care of it.
But they were busy hitting Singapore, Philippines,
They had no respect whatsoever.
They didn't even worry about American volunteers.
They figured, you know, that we were a polyglot mercenary outfit and that we probably wouldn't be able to find our way out of a paper bag.
We learned this subsequently.
Well, we went on alert, and of course, like I say, we were expected to be hit, but we
They went to some, you know, Pearl Harbor, all hell broke loose.
The United States was in a war, and then of course we got in a war against Europe, too.
I mean, active power.
Well, the fat was in a fire then, so some high-level conferences.
This pushed up the schedule for Chenault considerably.
And after some consultations with the British and the Chinese,
Not the American, but the British and Chinese.
Well, I guess America had to be in, because of the Lend-Lease airplane and all, but to my knowledge, it was primarily between the British and the Chinese.
One of our squadrons, we had three squadrons, 1st, 2nd, and 3rd Pursuit.
One of our squadrons, I think it was 3rd Squadron, would go down to Rangoon with the idea of protecting the port for the Burma Road to push the client into China.
The other two squadrons would immediately deploy up to Kunming, China, our main base that was being prepared for us in China, where we were all supposed to have gone.
The whole group should have gone, planned where.
And we were going to go, I think, planned where in the early part of 1942 we would have gone to.
Is that right here?
Yes, yes.
Sorry, our error.
Here's Kunming right here.
Tom Boo is right here just south of Young Yim here, and south of Mandalay, and that's where we were training here at Rand Goodman.
And so you flew up and over there?
Up and over the hump, that's the north part of the hump.
And when did you fly over the hump?
In December, we deployed up to Kunming on the 14th
December 1941, and on the 18th of December 1941 was my first taste of combat.
Okay, now before we get into the first taste of combat, tell me about flying over the hump.
Well, on that route from Canggu
northwest to Kunming, you really don't fly over the hump.
The real hump is between India and China.
And of course, I've flown over that.
But you just have no, in those days, no navigation aids whatsoever.
In our P-40, we had that old commercial radio set for air-to-air RTT.
but we had no nav aids whatsoever.
The only thing we used was a map, and I learned to navigate all over China and Burma and India by nothing in the world was flying the contours of the mountains.
The first time I ever flew over the hump was a P-40 with no contacts, I mean no nav aids.
The first time you flew what?
Over the hump.
Oh, okay, over the hump.
Actually, the first time I ever flew over the hump was in a P-43 later on, which I was
India into China.
But you might call this a partial flight over the southern part of the hump, because we did fly up by way of Lashio, which is just south of the Chinese Burma border, then almost due east to Kunming.
So you do fly over the southern part of the hump, and it's just a forbidding area, no roads, no nothing, except you see the Burma, the
Burma Road being built along the mountain to supply into China, southern China, because the Japanese blocked off the rest.
Now that's where all the elite support was to go to China, that Burma Road.
And that's what we were supposed to protect.
Instead, that was supposed to be the mission of the American Volunteer Group, protect the Burma Road from the Chinese.
I mean from the Japanese attack.
Now, what were your feelings when you knew that you were now finally en route to combat?
Just sheer excitement and eagerness.
I was ready and hot to try.
I just couldn't wait.
How about the excitement of your other 68 colleagues?
No, not 68.
Because a third of them went down south.
Oh, they were.
Did you have about 40 that went up with you?
Yeah, about two-thirds of us went up.
They did about three waves.
The happier ones were the ones that went to Rangoon because they figured they were going to get to combat before we would.
And they were much more excited.
It so turned out that we, who went to Kunming, actually got the first take to combat.
But within a few days, they at Rangoon really got involved in combat.
As a matter of fact, it was the 24th of May.
23rd, 24th, just for Christmas.
They really got tangled up, and from then on, it was every day that way.
But you were excited.
Oh, all of us were.
We felt we were trained.
We were confident.
I felt like a highly trained, hot-to-trot, typical American Air Force fighter wing pilot.
fight upon it.
We were confident.
We just couldn't wait to get in the fight, and particularly since, you know, they hit Pearl Harbor.
Oh man, you know, we were fired up.
And to me, a Jap was a savage, and there was only one way.
Kidding.
We were ready.
Really excited.
So, we just couldn't wait.
And every minute that
particularly when we get the Jimba, which is a Chinese air raid one, Jimba, air raid, which scrambled.
Boy, I tell you, it was, you found yourself breathing hard.
Okay, so you went up and you landed.
What were the conditions when you landed at Kunming?
I've seen some of the old pictures.
There's an old one.
Some old films that someone took right on the scene.
Yeah, I can show you plenty of them.
What were the conditions like at this era?
The field at Kunming was a grass field, but it was a good 5,000 feet square, plus down one side of it, the eastern side of it,
the Chinese coolies were building this huge, long, 5,000 foot, about 300 foot wide runway in anticipation of bombers, you know, every bomber from the United States.
And that just showed you how plans had been made.
And it was a typical- Was that a stone runway?
A typical Chinese construction, little broken up rocks by a Chinaman with a hammer.
carried in baskets and dumped, and then following him was another guy with some pots with sloppy mud to pour on top of it, red clay.
It would get hard.
It'd be just, if you will, sort of a concrete mixture, and it made a stone runway, and it was about two feet thick.
And that would hold a B-17 easy.
As a matter of fact, B-17s and B-24s used that very well.
They were building it then.
We didn't use it.
We used the grass off the side.
They had our dormitories were just spotless.
Each pilot had his own bunk.
Just a little dormitory room, you know.
But common.
Everybody had their own little room?
Everybody.
By how large?
My room was a little bit bigger than this.
Yeah, I'd say 12 by 12.
I forget.
Actually I'd say it was about nine by twelve.
It was a cot, regular army type cot with a good mattress on it.
Heated particularly at night in the coldest time.
Well in the morning a little cooler, you'd come in about six o'clock with a charcoal brazier.
That was heater room in the cold.
We had lights.
and common latrine facilities down the way.
We had a common dining hall and a club, if you will, where the men and the officers, so-called officers and men, we had no real separation over there.
This was some regulations and rules, very few, only an absolute medal had been put out by Chenault.
I was a little bit
surprised and wondering for a while how this thing was going to operate because there was no rules and regulations involved.
You know, strictly military discipline then.
And I was just wondering, and knowing what, having heard of mercenary outfits, I wondered, you know, maybe this is what this was.
But it proved later on to me that we, in my opinion, the American Volunteer Group was not a mercenary outfit per se, I assure you.
We were a well-trained, close-knit, extremely competent fighter group.
What was the difference between a professional fighter group and a mercenary?
The difference was ours was an outfit that held together and proved itself in combat.
A mercenary outfit was

from, if you will, civilian type commercial pilots, maybe one or two dishonorably discharged military type, maybe from Poland, Canada, one or two from the United States, even some Russian pilots with some beat up equipment, maybe some Chinese, I mean some Russian equipment, that just didn't hold together.
We were a
And like I told you recently, we were picked for the cream of the crop of the trained guys.
How would you like to be, I put your question, how would you like to be a commander?
You can't ask me a question.
That's not fair.
But I'm doing this rhetorically.
And I'm a commander type of one.
And I look back upon this.
Here we are.
Here is Chenault, the commander.
And he just reaches out and picks trains
very capably trained people for an air force.
And then gives them an airplane, and he got made.
Really, you would ask me about training a while ago?
We didn't have a hell of a lot of training.
We just indoctrinated each other.
And then the problem was, of course, holding each other together.
Well, and I actually- So that's the difference between mercenaries and- Okay, so you were really a well-trained
group of professionals with outstanding equipment?
To be the Chinese Air Force.
Okay, okay.
Now let's go back here.
I want to ask you one question.
We were talking about conditions, and you described your room.
How about your food?
The food, well, the food was good.
As a matter of fact, it was American food, American-style food.
Eggs, oh, eggs.
We had, every once in a while they had fresh beef.
And vegetables, you know, China, the Chinese have terrific vegetables.
But chicken, they've got sick chicken in the line.
We'd eat chicken morning, noon, and night.
A lot of times I had fried chicken for breakfast.
Really?
Dude chicken.
This was later on when it got a little bit difficult to get, during the war, got a little difficult to get other types of food.
But generally speaking, the food was good, adequate.
It was very good and adequate down in Burma.
Well, what about...
how you ate compared to how the average Kool-Aid or the average person ate?
Oh, no comparison.

We ate like, well we ate, actually, I'd say we probably ate better than the average, I know we did, we ate better than the average United States serviceman, let's say that rushed over to India or to Southwest Asia.
We ate better.
Because it was an established
mass upon the Chinese logistic structure.
They were already in place.
And Len Leith was already shipping food over there.
How'd you get along with your coolie?
Did you have servants?
Well, we had common servants.
For instance, my little barber cut my hair for two cents.

and we had to speak broken immediately we started you know broken Chinese and they'd pick up broken English we'd pick up broken Chinese and the cootie that would come in with my brazier in the morning he wouldn't even wake me up he'd just come in get the pot go out get the charcoal going and bring it back in and leave maybe I'd see him in the afternoon clean up the room we'd have paid them a cent the place was kept immaculate and laundry
was, you know, you've always heard of Chinese laundromat.
They did that every day, and we just, they'd pick it up.
It was, in effect, we had homemade maids, and they provided the KP's for cooking.
The grounds was kept neat, and the
The structures were well built, plaster and- Did they serve you plaster and brick?
Plaster, but adobe brick.
Did the Chinese serve you when you ate dinner?
Yes.
Did they cook the food?
They cooked the food and served it at the table just like an officer's club.
As a matter of fact, we'd have a choice of menu of maybe two or three.
Like in the morning we'd have eggs any style.
Every once in a while they'd have a bacon that was sort of a local style bacon, but it tasted like bacon.
Eventually we got American food and had American bacon.
At lunch we'd have soup, always have soup.
Sometimes have soup breakfast if you wanted to.
Yeah, we got milk.
I don't know where it came from, but at times we got milk and it was good.
In between missions, did you ever have any time off, or was there a town nearby or anything?
Yes, yes.
And did you go into that town?
How were you treated by the people?
Yeah, we were in a town in the city of Kunming.
Now Kunming, area-wise, is about the size of, let's say,
geographic-wise and area-wise, say the size of Austin.
But when I was there in the early part of the war, when some refugees had come into it, the population was about 400,000.
We'd go into town, see we'd have regular training days, and about once a week we'd have a day off.

had a few old jalopy type sedans that was at our disposal, and viewers would get together, go into town, and they had a theater with printed American, English subtitles, and very nice restaurants, some very nice restaurants, and other parts of the city of course over typical Far Eastern just pitifully
poverty-stricken and bedraggled Chinese with eating on the sidewalk and streets were filthy, typical for East Sloan.
And we'd buy maybe some satin coverlets to send home that you put over a, make a quilt with.
Sure.
Real satin, beautiful thing.
with cars with sewn embroidered Chinese dragons on it.
As a matter of fact, sent a lot of those.
Pillowcases and things like that?
Yeah.
But other than that.
Well, how'd you get along with the people when you went in?
Our relations with the Chinese people were practically nil.
Naturally, you know, driving in town, we had.
A tragic time.
Oh, yeah.
And of course, driving down the street was the hardest thing in the world to get them out of your way.
We continued on the horn.
There were practically no vehicles in the city at all.
Bicycles up to the zoo, but people mostly on foot.
They knew who we were.
The people really who minded to running the business of the city and the higher levels of Chinese population, they knew who we were and knew what our purpose was, and they loved us.
The social stories were given by the governor, the mayor, some of the wealthier citizens, and some of us were invited for dinners.
We didn't necessarily have to eat with chopsticks.
We had our own, in effect, PX, if you will.
It was small, as it was, but in a liquor store.
To buy a bottle of liquor, I remember on Christmas Day in Chungking, yeah, no, Christmas Day in Kunming, I and two others paid $52 a barrel
You were thirsty.
That was George Burgoyne and Jim Costner again, the two I told you about.
All three of us got in the same squadron.
But every once in a while, the British would come in with a supply of liquor.
And they were practically giving us for nothing, a ration.
We lived comfortably.
We had plenty of black clothing.
And uniforms, there was no... What uniforms we... Well, we're going to get to uniforms and regulations.
But before we do, when you went into town, did the people treat you well because they thought that you were there to defend them?
Or how did they treat you?
Well, our relations with the Chinese civilians, if you will, in town were, like I say, practically nailed.
If we'd go into a store to buy something,
communication-wise, English and Chinese, you know, we couldn't speak.
Every once in a while, you'd run across one who would interpret, could speak a few words.
But we'd haggle on prices, and generally they would give, just because of their respect for us, and they'd give us a terrific discount on something you would buy, for instance.
Always gay and laughing, because they were happy, you know, these American heroes would come into my place and finish them.
We were heroes to them, and particularly after we started shooting from our plant down.
Now we became widespread heroes.
Like Madam said, we were her little angels.
They treated us well.

I don't remember ever, ever any group, even when they're getting in maybe a drunken, two or three of them getting in a drunken riot, maybe in a local restaurant, never really any trouble coming from them.
Whenever we'd go to a social gathering, it was similar to, let's say, one right here in the United States.
It was just as nice a host and courteous and extremely happy to have us as guests.
Some of them would, at times, we'd have an affair out at the base.
